qas.question: Laws mandated that every able bodies Japanese citizen do what?

answers.text: serve a mandatory term of three years with the first reserves and two additional years with the second reserves.

qas.question: Who initially rejected the Japanese laws mandating military service?
What did the peasant class name the mandatory military service law?
Who did the Japanese form their military  forces after?
Where was the military academy located?

context: Laws were instituted that required every able-bodied male Japanese citizen, regardless of class, to <a0_0>serve a mandatory term of three years with the first reserves and two additional years with the second reserves.<a0_0/> This action, the deathblow for the samurai warriors and their daimyo feudal lords, initially met resistance from both the <a1_0>peasant and warrior alike.<a1_0/> The peasant class interpreted the term for military service, <a2_0>ketsu-eki<a2_0/> (blood tax) literally, and attempted to avoid service by any means necessary. The Japanese government began modelling their ground forces after the <a3_0>French military<a3_0/>. The French government contributed greatly to the training of Japanese officers. Many were employed at the military academy in <a4_0>Kyoto<a4_0/>, and many more still were feverishly translating French field manuals for use in the Japanese ranks.
